content.description: The crux is pulling off the ground in a thin finger crack dihedral. Follow the dihedral to a ledge. Work up the face using good pro in horizontal cracks. When the face above gets really dirty, step left and encounter a second short crux before more easy climbing to the top.
content.protection: Standard Rack with an Optional #4. Be prepared to build a gear anchor. The only tree near the top of this route is completely dead and would not be safe for belay or repel. This route would actually be an excellent candidate for a bolted anchor.
content.location: 15 ft right of an arete. Look for a hanging dihedral with a little finger crack. (See crappy picture)

content.description: A low crux on beautiful, clean and vertical rock lead to a pumpy chickenhead finish.
content.protection: quickdraws and a 4-ft sling for a monster chickenhead
content.location: Meets up with "Bearing Teeth" around the 4th bolt.

content.description: Begin in a right facing corner under a small roof. Turn the corner to the first bolt, pull through the short crux, and finish on the short overhung face above.
content.location: Around the corner from Wonderwall. The wall features a prominent low roof that ends just above the start of the climb.

climbs.name: Jason Cook's Total Body Workout
climbs.fa: Cole Fennel, Stark Legion, Jordan Hill

content.description: Sustained route that will leave you feeling worked. Climb crimps to first bolt fending off the pump until you reach the footless crux at the second roof. One last big move leads to jugs to a third roof and the finish**This route may now be unclimbable due to rock breakage. Â Please inform if you climb this route post 2018**
This is a dirty dihedral with super fun stemming and a few good steep jams pulling over a bulge near the top. I loved it and my girlfriend hated it.
content.protection: Standard Rack to #4. Bolted anchor with chains.
content.location: Right of bearing teeth. Obvious right facing dihedral.

content.description:
The crux is at the start simply because your first piece of pro is placed 15-20 feet up.   After that, finding holds and placing pro is easy. 

  The route name is a Blade Runner reference.
content.protection: I used a standard rack up to 4, but I probably could have done the route only with hexagonals and slings.  Shares anchors with Cackling Hens
content.location: Find this route about 20 feet to the right of Cackling Hens.  Ascend a smooth face to an obvious vertical crack. Enjoy the crack as it curves to the right.  Eventually move out onto the face and head for the anchors.

content.description: This route is very beautiful and much easier than it appears. In some ways, it reminds me of a more moderate version of For Whom the Bell Tolls at Haw Creek. Cackling Hens looks like a genuine crack climb, but an abundance of face holds and good stances make it accessible to the average Arkansas face climber. The crux is at the first roof.
content.protection: Standard Rack. Might bring a few extra red and green Camelots if you have them. Bolted anchor with chains.
content.location: Right of Hidden Treasure. Look for an obvious right leaning crack under an impressive tiered roof system.

content.description: Begin with a difficult boulder problem below the first bolt. Follow bolts angling left across a crimpy vertical face. Pull the roof using huge jugs and continue up the juggy but pumpy face.
content.protection: 6 bolts. Bring a sling for the huge chicken head after the last bolt or you will face a 20 ft run out on easy terrain. 2 bolt anchor equipped for lowering.
content.location: Two obvious bolt lines intersect under a roof. This is the bolt line on the right. See picture.

content.description: The north side of Stack Rock. This wall contains a large collection of quality routes. Cole Fennel does not give it a name in "Rock Climbing Arkansas," so I'm using North Wall to designate everything from MTA to Nomar Wall.
